Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of an Advanced Positron Beam System for Annihilation Spectroscopies of Surfaces, Interfaces and Nanostructures
Award.AbstractNarration:
1338130
Weiss

Technical Abstract:

This Major Research Instrumentation Award to the University of Texas at Arlington supports the development of a next generation high flux variable energy spin-polarized positron beam instrument for materials research. When completed the system will be the first in the world capable of performing time of flight Positron Annihilation induced Auger Electron Spectroscopy (PAES) and gamma-gamma spectroscopy utilizing a spin polarized positron beam. The spectra of Auger electrons and gamma rays emitted as a result of the annihilation of low energy positrons implanted into the sample will be used to obtain unique information about the chemical composition and structure of materials. The instrument will have a high degree of selectivity for surfaces and sensitivity to open volume defects due to the trapping of positrons prior to annihilation. The positrons will be obtained using a 22Na source and a high efficiency Ne moderator system designed to preserve the polarization of the positrons. This will enable spin dependent measurements and will be particularly useful for the study of the origin of the unusual magnetic properties associated with otherwise non-magnetic materials that show large magnetic moments associated with defects. The unique information provided by the advanced positron beam system regarding the elemental content, defect type and defect concentration of surfaces and nano-structures holds the potential to enable breakthrough discoveries in areas including nano-magnetism, high energy product magnetic materials, photo-catalysis, nano-particle photoluminescence, and tribology. This project will provide training opportunities for undergraduate, graduate, and post-doctoral researchers in the development and application of advanced instruments for the characterization of materials.

Non-technical Abstract:
This award from the Major Research Instrumentation program supports the University of Texas at Arlington with the development of a next generation instrument for the characterization of materials utilizing a beam of low energy positrons (anti-matter electrons). When completed the instrument will be the first in the world to combine spin polarization with a time of flight Positron Annihilation induced Auger Electron Spectroscopy (PAES) and gamma-gamma spectroscopy. Positrons emitted from a radioactive source will be implanted at a selected depth below the surface. An analysis of the distribution of energies of the gamma-rays and electrons emitted when the positrons annihilate will provide unique information regarding the elemental content and physical structure of surfaces and near surface voids and missing atom defects. The unique information provided by the advanced beam system will enable new discoveries in areas including the development of nano-particle based supermagnets, the development of new catalysts that can absorb light and promote the splitting of water to make hydrogen for fuel, and for the study of friction caused by submicroscopic carbon soot. This project will provide training opportunities for undergraduate, graduate, and post-doctoral researchers in the design, construction, and application of advanced instruments for the characterization of materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has resulted in the development of an advanced variable energy antimatter beam at the University of Texas at Arlington (UTA) for material studies. The beam uses a state of the art cryogenic rare gas moderator system that can produce a beam of positrons (the antimatter equivalent of the electrons).  The moderator slows down the fast positrons emitted from a radioactive source (22Na).  By using a high efficiency cryogenic rare gas moderator system we have been able to achieve ten times the positron flux of our previous beam systems at UTA. The advanced positron beam system developed in this project is the first in the world that combines positron annihilation induced Auger electron spectroscopy (PAES), developed in our lab at UTA, with beam-based 2 detector annihilation gamma spectroscopy. This combination will provide unique electronic, structural and chemical information from the top atomic layer of surfaces and inner surfaces with surface selectivity presently unavailable with other electron or photon-based spectroscopies.

The use of two detectors to measure both the annihilation gammas produced during an annihilation event has resulted in more than an order of magnitude decrease in the background in the high energy region of the gamma energy spectrum. This reduction in the background along with the use of very low energy positrons has allowed us to investigate a few layers of graphene deposited on copper. Our investigations demonstrated the surface sensitivity of the two detector gamma spectroscopy and brought out the interaction pathways of positrons with a 2-dimensional material like graphene. In addition to giving information on the chemical structure of the top atomic layer, the annihilation gamma spectroscopy also gives information on the formation of positronium, (an exotic atom made of an electron and a positron), as a function of the energy of the incident positrons. Our application of PAES to graphene on copper has resulted in the first direct observation of a unique electron emission process from a single layer of carbon atoms that was known to exist but has not been observed before. Our results indicate that this electron emission process can be utilized to develop a new electron spectroscopy that can give information on the behavior of electrons on the top atomic layer.

The novel techniques utilizing the new positron beam system developed under this project provide innovative non-destructive methods of materials characterization.  The new system and its unique capabilities have been made available to faculty at UTA involved in thin-film and materials research. Our research has shown that the new beam system, when used with very low beam energies, can efficiently and selectively probe fragile systems like 2D materials without beam induced modification of the sample. The unique information regarding the electronic structure, elemental content, defect types, and defect concentration at surfaces can be expected to enable breakthrough discoveries in a number of areas including nano-magnetism, high energy product magnetic materials, photo-catalysis, nano-particle photoluminescence, and tribology.

Materials studies carried out using the new beam system have been published in peer-reviewed journals of high impact. The results were also disseminated through presentations by postdoctoral scholar and graduate students at international conferences.

The project has provided training in advanced ultra-high vacuum techniques, data acquisition, and analysis, complimentary spectroscopic techniques and in the presentation of data to four undergraduate students, two MS students, five Ph.D. students and one senior Postdoctoral Fellow.   The students were selected from the highly diverse community in UTA and we were able to give training in laboratory practices to the traditionally underrepresented population in the STEM.

The unique capabilities of the new system to employ a low energy beam of positrons to make simultaneous measurements of the Doppler-broadened annihilation spectrum and the positron annihilation induced electron emission spectra has opened up new avenues of research in the field of porous materials and 2D materials. The system developed under this project provides a major new resource to researchers involved in the study of these materials here at the University of Texas at Arlington and their collaborators worldwide.
